title: Individualized Services Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at Partnerships in Community Living (Monmouth, OR) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: The process was somewhat long, but it was more fun than any other group interview i had been to in the past. About 17 people sat in a room which was set up like a panel of some kind. The first 20 ish minutes is a woman talking to the group about the company and what it stands for. We are then split up in groups for a group activity where we go into a room and are given a team project. For the project, we were given spaghetti noodles, a marshmallow, and tape and were asked to figure out how to get the marshmallow to stand at least 20 inches in the air. It took us about 5 minutes to come up with an idea and we nailed it! At the same time in the other room, the other group is being interviewed in a sort of speed dating way. you are asked about 5 questions (all pretty straight forward) from 5 different employees, and then the groups switch. At some point, i can't remember when, we did a computer skills worksheet, if you have ever used gmail, its very simple to follow.  this whole process was about an hour and a half and i heard back the next day by 5!
Interview Questions: If you won a million dollars what is the first thing you would do?

title: Direct Support Professional Interview

title: Direct Support Professional Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Partnerships in Community Living (Monmouth, OR) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions:
It is a group interview with 3 different parts;

1. Computer Skills: show that you understand how to turn on a laptop and open and log into gmail (there are instructions in case you don't know how)

2. Craft Project: you and 2-3 other people have x amount of time (3 minutes? 5 minutes?) to build a structure that will support a dixie cup of water for 60 seconds using rolled papers, markers, and tape. This is to show team work. They will ask you about how you felt about this exercise. MAKE SURE your answers center around team work and try to act like a leader during this (not take over the project) but definitely speak up and give your opinions and suggestions. They're looking for team oriented people because thats literally the basis of this whole company.

3. Group Interview: first, they go around the room and ask people different questions that are honestly kind of silly. Then, your potential supervisor will come to you one-on-one and ask you more silly questions, as well as some actual interview questions. 

**Your answers to any of these questions should include; your ability to work as a team, communicate with your superiors, and your ability and willingness to find answers if you don't know them. Don't be afraid to throw some humor in there as well (appropriate of course), it shows the hiring staff that you can be silly with the clients and have fun. As long as you are extremely positive, dressed somewhat professionally, and can think level headed, you are almost guaranteed a job here. I was called the next day and offered the job and was employed over 3 years**
Interview Questions: What kind of car would you be?
